name: Addis Ababa
fun_fact: Fun fact: Doro Wat recipes date back to the Aksumite Empire (circa 100-940 CE), one of the four great powers of the ancient world - making Ethiopian cuisine one of the oldest continuous culinary traditions on Earth!

hero_dishes.name: Doro Wat
hero_dishes.description: Deeply spiced chicken stew with berbere and niter kibbeh (spiced butter), hard-boiled eggs
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ethiopia's national dish dating back to Sumerian times, mentioned in Babylonian Talmud

hero_dishes.name: Injera
hero_dishes.description: Spongy fermented flatbread made from teff flour, used as plate and utensil
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made from teff, a grain native to Horn of Africa, cultivated since Aksumite era
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every Ethiopian restaurant - food is served on top of injera

hero_dishes.name: Tibs
hero_dishes.description: SautÃ©ed meat (lamb or beef) with onions, garlic, peppers, and mitmita spice
hero_dishes.origin_story: Simple, flavorful dish celebrated across Ethiopia

hero_dishes.name: Kitfo
hero_dishes.description: Ethiopian steak tartare - raw minced beef with spiced butter and mitmita
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made from the softest, reddest parts of the meat
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Specialty restaurants, often served with ayib (fresh cheese)

signature_drinks.name: Ethiopian Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Coffee originated in Ethiopia - traditional ceremony involves roasting, grinding, brewing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: In buna (coffee) ceremonies that can last hours, served in small cups

food_culture_notes: Vegetables locally sourced, meat from freshly killed animals - nothing mass-produced
Wednesdays and Fridays are fasting days - shiro wat (chickpea stew) served instead
Yod Abyssinia designed like traditional hut with woven grass serving dishes
Sharing Doro Wat is communal - everyone eats from same large injera
